Award.AbstractNarration: This project investigates in much more detail the human anatomy and dynamics to further progress in replicating human articulation capabilities. To overcome long-standing imaging limitations, the project follows a data-driven approach, in which sampled dynamic motion data is used to infer unknown parameters such as soft-tissue geometry and behavior. The project is cross-disciplinary and driven by specific problems in orthopaedics and human character animation, although its focus is fundamentally on computational and automated analysis tools. The research plan develops computational tools for capturing robustly and accurately dynamic skeletal motion from medical images, for inferring biological shape and behavior from dynamic motion information, and for representing and calculating with these data. The education effort is naturally integrated with the research work, and includes recruiting and training graduate, undergraduate, and high-school students into multi-disciplinary work, through a modeling and simulation approach to teaching computer graphics. The outcome of the project is a set of human-anatomy based (i.e., humanoid) models of articulations that impacts orthopaedists' understanding of articulation injury and disease, leads to improved diagnosis and medical treatment, and improves the realism of digital character animation. The broad impact of the project includes applications in biology, bioengineering, ergonomics, evolutionary biology and robotics. Results of this project, including software, data, and publications, are publicly available through the project web site, http://vis.cs.pitt.edu/marai_nsf_career

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award has supported research into medical computing and physically-based modeling and their applications, coupled with an educational framework for identifying and teaching the skills needed for successful multi-disciplinary research. The education effort was integrated with the research plan, which included development of computational tools for capturing biological shape and dynamic motion from the bone-level up, representing them within the computer, and using those representations for specific applications in biological modeling.

Results from this work include: 1) intelligent 3D motion reconstruction algorithms that match the accuracy of expert human operators, while reducing human labor by a factor of 9; these algorithms use temporal and spatial coherence in biomedical data to increase robustness; 2) computational representations and algorithms that use accurate reconstruction of skeletal 3D motion to infer previously undetectable soft-tissues properties; these representations make possible insights into surgical spine procedures; 3) scientific open-source software for biological modeling that has been adopted by thousands of users; 4) a US patent with multiple innovation points derived from this work; 5) a technology transfer to industry; 6) significant accomplishments in several multi-disciplinary settings, including astronomy and biophysics. 

An extension of this work helps create a novel statistical and computational methodology for dynamic and personalized oncology treatment decisions over time, with specific application to head and neck cancer radiotherapy planning.

This body of research has been recognized by peers with many refereed journal articles, as well as peer-reviewed conference papers and book chapters, and by multiple Outstanding Research awards at conferences. This research has also been featured on journal and newsletter covers.

The award has provided partial support for 3 PhD students (two graduated) and 4 MS students (3 graduated). Supplements to this award have provided more than 20 undergraduate students with research opportunities. Several of these students have received honors and awards for the work done under this project. 

This award has also made possible innovative curriculum developments. The PI has received six teaching awards for courses that blend teaching and research.

Outreach efforts made possible by this award include bootcamps and workshops for underrepresented students, as well as multiple demonstrations of state of the art technology to K-12 students, college students and their families, and to state and administration officials.
